body.p:
Your friendly and consoling letters have
remained too long unanswered, and the delay is not so much
attributable to want of time as to depression of spirit which grows
daily upon me from a variety of causes, among which may be briefly
enumerated the state of my wife's health (she is now a confirmed
invalid) the unpromising state of my affairs, and isolation from all
society. It grieves me to write in so dolorous a strain, and yet it is a
relief to unto? myself to one who knew me in happier days, and who
can sympathize in my distresses. You have so much to endure that I
am almost ashamed to make your heart ache with the recital of my troubles.
God's will be done! A wise, merciful and loving Father watches over us; He
knows what is good for us. Therefore while acknowledging with fortitude
כי כל על פטרו אמת—my watchword in the conflict with the world and
adverse circumstances is קוה אל ה' חזק והאמון לבך. This upholds me; and the
thought that if I suffer in this life, there will be less to undergo hereafter
gives me cheerfulness in the darkest moments.

I am truly thankful for your counsel, and cheered by the hopes you hold out that I may
yet do something in the states should I determine on quitting this place.
This year will solve the problem whether I remain or not. My wife's
state of health will, unless she can be cured in another country which I
doubt, under her incapable of superintending a boarding school, and a
daily one is, with the accesibility of Jewish children to the American
schools, free, gratis, for nothing, out of question. There remains then the
ancient precedent; but our people have in the Psalmists words ובלעדו א"א עליהם
ויתערבו בגורם. Their ideas are that the Jewish ministry should be hierarchi-
cal, and even should any congregation satisfied with my antecedents
not object to engaging me, my age, for remember I am now 50 might
be an obstacle. I am also rusty from disuse, having now been 4 years
away from the desk and pulpit. A little hard study might again
revive my latent powers, and sage experience and calm reasoning supply
the void caused by the loss of imagination, which nevertheless delights
popular assemblies whether lay or clerical. There is stuff in me yet.
For the present, however, I must suspend all action; but will let you

know as the time approaches for decision. Meanwhile your warm
and affectionate interest in Mrs. N and me is a source of great
comfort in my tribulation טוב ריע מאח.

Before quitting the subject of myself it is as well to tell you that my
duties have become onerous since the death of my brother in law. His
mother is now under my care; she has no living relative but her daughter,
and should any thing happen to me, neither of them has, in this wide
world one from whom they could morally and socially claim as a
guardian or protector. This country is fallen and falling, and I
apprehend, should there be no amendment, that numbers, particularly of
one creed will quit. I have also obligations to discharge to the orphans
and widow of the deceased; and it is my earnest hope and constant
prayer that I may live to educate the former in a civilized and religious
community. Having never been blessed with children, how tranquil
and peaceful would be my last moments if, after having trained these
dear ones in the ways of piety and holiness, I could depart this world
with the consciousness of having done my utmost to discharge faithfully
the truth reposed in me.

Let me devote the remaining portion of the sheet to you. You write
and think in a tone of dejection and almost bitterness which is
foreign to your heart as an Israelite, to your feelings as a God-fearing
God serving man. As it always was and always will be till האות לנצח
בלע; each thinks his burden the heaviest. Yours has not been light.
Ill treatment, malevolence and ? have spirited their renown
on your name and reputation. Your sensitive spirit has winced under
the attacks of ignorance, prejudice, and jealousy. You have manfully
fought and reasoned with your enemies; have worked hard to remove
the injustice ascribed to your motives and actions, sometimes successfully,
most frequently not. Envy has bela? and will never cease to
buffet you. It has cried and still exclaims as Korah spoke to
Moses & Aaron הם לך “You take too much upon you.” For, bear in mind,
you have exposed abuses, you have cried down irreligion, you have
unveiled vicious practices in קהל ועדה. I believe and ever shall that
singliness of heart prompted all you have spoken, written and done.
There are many who think with me in both Hemispheres and in the
איר הים, In our opinion your detractors may rail, congregations
both orthodox and reformed may turn a deaf ear to your suggestions,

decry your efforts, refuse your advice as a guide—but they cannot
gainsay? the truth that for upwards of a quarter of a century you
have defended and instructed Israel on the wide field of the United
States, that your sermons, translations of Prayers and Bible, Catechisms
&c have enlightened old and young American Jews owe you a large
debt of gratitude. But they won't acknowledge it say you. “There's the
rub” Friend Leeser! Our people are eminently conservative. They like
the old land ? when these are not in the way of their interests, their
passion, and worldly progress. They can plead precidents derived from
Holy write for treating you as they do. Their ancestors did the same to
Legislator and King and Prophet. The character of Moses has outlived
the foul assersions of a Korah, Datban & ?; David's memory is
now the worse for the rituperation? of shrines, nor is Jeremiah less venerated
for having been thrust in the stocks and dungeon. You must bear
patiently for the score of years you may yet live Posterity will do
you justice, and the name and fame of Isaac Leeser will be the
theme of a future Jewish historian. It will rank you as the
hardy pioneer of Israel, whom no danger deterred, no peril dismayed.
I am a man as feeble in words as deficient in influence, and
my ? cannot benefit you here or hereafter. But חי ה'
I most conscientiously and truly believe that you have insured
your reward already in another and a better world. You may rest
on your ? without being chargeable with sloth and indolence if
your arms ache with toil; and throw for the winds whatever may
tend to exasperate your heart and feelings. After all this I write וד"ל

I have sold the copies of the Quarto Bible you sent me, the morocco
bound small ones, except I believe, a single copy, and one or two of
the others. The money shall be collected and remitted you by next
steamer if possible. I feel all the better after writing this
long ?. The exercise has done me good the reading of it
may or may not pare a like effect in you, especially my
קרנות. Of one thing however be assured that I have not abated
one jot in my sincere feeling towards you, nor my honest
appreciation of your merits.

The news of Jacob De la Motta's death gave me a great shock.
He was only the acquaintance of a single day, and yet I
esteemed him a friend. Savannah loses a good citizen

body.p:
and our people there one whom they could ill spare. Our old Shammash
Joseph Joseph has gone to rest. He had served the congregation in and
out of office for twenty five years. His age was about 70

I often entertain the desire of writing Miss Gratz
but am uncertain whether I should do so after having ceased
corresponding for so many years. Please remember me and
Mrs N affectionately to her and all inquiring friends.
Long ere this you will have met with Mis Peixotto
to whom name us kindly. When will your new weekly
publication appear? I will try whether I cannot obtain
subscribers. The Jewish Community here is rapidly
degenerating not a particle of spirit about them; tho' the
sabbath continues to be observed by the Greater number
of the German Congregation. The Revd Mr Davis is a good
Chazan, and is improving in his sermons.

May the almighty grant you health
happiness and prosperity always.
